title: Diploma in Food Skills and Techniques
headline: Learn the food skills and techniques needed to excel in the catering and restaurant industry with this free course.
description: This course offers a broad overview of various food preparation skills and techniques. It starts with how to prepare stock and the various ingredients used for different types of stock. Then consider individual cuts of meat and the dishes for which each is most suitable. In addition, this course covers the sweeter side of cooking – baking. It will take you through some of the methods and skills needed to make a variety of desserts.
courseDescription:
This free cooking course will cover a broad overview of various food preparation skills, cooking methods and more advanced techniques. One of the many building blocks for a chef to learn is making stock, an essential component in many dishes and the base for many sauces. Learn why, once a stock has been made, you need to follow the correct cooling down, storing and reheating methods in order to avoid bacteria growth. Next, see why sauces are crucial in marrying individual components and providing an explosion of flavour. Meat is the centre of many cuisines, courses and dishes so it is important to know the three categories domestic meat is usually divided into. Which is the generally the most prized and commands the highest prices? How does the quality differ depending on the type of animal it is derived from? How have breeders changed the qualities of certain meats to be leaner and lower in fat? Can some types of meats harbour a specific parasite that can cause serious health risks?

Poultry and seafood are also popular ingredients that, like meat, are significant sources of protein. The first group includes at least eight different types of birds and the course breaks down the most and least popular joints. It also covers what to look for when choosing seafood and how to tell if it is fresh or not. Gutting fish correctly is a crucial skill for all cooks to know, and the material will show you how to do so properly to avoid the guts releasing an enzyme that quickly spoils the fish. You will consider the types, anatomy and cooking of shellfish and cephalopods, which are also part of the seafood group. Finally, you will study the plethora of ‘side dishes’, including vegetables, grains and pasta. Learn how we have cultivated grains for centuries, including wheat, rice, quinoa, barley and many others, and see why pasta may be considered to belong to the grain family. Learn how combining flour and eggs or water creates pasta, and why making fresh pasta can produce a richer flavour.

Lastly, this free course focuses on desserts, many of which require highly specialised techniques to execute correctly. Whether made from chocolate or vanilla, or served hot to cold, being able to make a variety of desserts is crucial to being a well-rounded cook or chef. This course is essential for anyone who would like to brush up on their food skills in the kitchen, whether you are a home cook or a professional chef who is just starting out. By mastering the essential skills and techniques contained in this course, you will also be able to create your own dishes because you will have a solid foundation of methods and a knowledge of stocks, sauces, meats, side dishes and desserts. You will also conquer food waste and, of you own a restaurant or catering company, see how correct food storage and preparation can increase your gross profit. Stay-at-home parents, students, childminders and even carers can benefit from completing this beneficial food skills and techniques course.

Start Course Now

slides:
• Learning Outcomes

  • By the end of this module you will be able to:
    • Classify the different types of stocks.
    • Identify the 6 stages that stocks are made in.
    • Recall the correct temperature when cooling, storing and reheating a stock. 
    • Select the appropriate vegetable for a dish, according to its taste and aroma. 
    • Recognize the various methods of cooking a potato. 
    • Label the 5 main categories of fruit.

  • Introduction

  • “Indeed, stock is everything in cooking [...] without it, nothing can be done.”
    - Auguste Escoffier
  • Stocks form the backbone of classical cookery. They are an essential component in many dishes and form the basis of all meat sauces. 

    A stock is simply an extraction of flavour from meat, poultry, vegetables or other ingredients into water. The water is infused with the flavour of the stock ingredients, producing a base liquid from which other dishes can be produced.

  • Cooling & Storage of Stocks

  • Once a stock has been made, and the desired flavour and consistency has been achieved, it should be chilled down to 5°C as quickly as possible. The best method for cooling is to use a blast chiller, or to pour the stock into shallow trays in order to increase its surface area, allowing it to cool more quickly. 

    White, brown and vegetables stocks have a high protein content, which puts them at risk of bacterial contamination. Once cooled, stocks should be covered, labelled and kept refrigerated at 5°C or below. They can also be frozen at -18°C or lower. Stocks must always be reheated to boiling point for 2 minutes before use. This will destroy any harmful bacteria. Ideally, stocks should be made fresh each day and discarded at the end of service.

  • Sauces 

  • Sauces are an integral part of any dish. They serve to marry the components of a dish, adding richness, moisture, and an additional layer of flavour and texture. It is often said that all sauces have their origins in one of the five ‘mother sauces’ - béchamel, velouté, Espagnole, sauce tomat, and Hollandaise.

    There is merit in this argument, as much of western cuisine is based on classical French cookery, of which these sauces are a staple. However, modern cooking techniques take influence from much further afield - East Asia, South America, North Africa, to name a few - so the repertoire has now grown somewhat. Four of the five mother sauces are thickened with flour, making them rather heavy; modern palates tend to prefer a lighter approach.

    During the early part of the twentieth century, Auguste Escoffier published Le Guide Culinaire, in which he stated his five ‘mother sauces’ from which all subsequent sauces could be derived. This was itself a continuation of earlier work by another great French chef, Antoine Carême.

    Carême had originally categorized four mother sauces - Espagnole, Allemande, béchamel and velouté. Escoffier decided that sauce Allemande was essentially a variation on a velouté, so he reclassified it as a secondary sauce, replacing it with sauce tomat and adding a fifth sauce to the list: Hollandaise.

  • Groups of Fruit and Vegetables

  • Fruits and vegetables are by far the largest food groups you will come across as a caterer. It is a wide and varied group containing plants, herbs and fungi that can be prepared as a meal in themselves or as an accompaniment to a meat protein.

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • Both fruits and vegetables can be divided into separate groups and sub-groups, determined by how they grow, the part of the plant being used, and the particular species.

    Over the next pages, we will discuss the groups most commonly used to differentiate fruits and vegetables.

  • Groups of Fruit and Vegetables

  • Roots and Tubers

  • Roots and tubers are those hard vegetables that grow underground. Potatoes are a part of this group, but as they are such a widely used ingredient with a huge number of varieties they are given their own dedicated group.

    Many roots and tubers can be prepared in much the same way as potatoes - everything from boiling, steaming, mashing and puréeing, to baking, roasting, frying and confît. Over the next three pages, we will cover twelve different types of roots and tubers.

  • Pods

  • The pods include fresh beans, peas and okra; vegetables which have seeds that mature inside a pod. Some can be eaten whole, such as mangetout or sugar snap peas; others, like broad beans and garden peas, must be shelled. 

    Mangetout, sugar snap and fine beans- These can be eaten whole when young and fresh. Fresh pods will snap between the fingers when bent - older or poor quality pods will bend.

    Runner beans and French beans- These can be eaten whole, but should be trimmed at either end, de-stringed before cooking, or sliced. To de-string, top and tail the beans and pull away the fine cord of fibre that runs down the back of each bean.

    Peas and broad beans- They both must be shelled before eating. To do this, simply twist one end of the pod and open it up along the seam. Their fine inside membrane grows tougher as the pod matures. Very young broad beans are tender and can be eaten without removing this membrane, but most will need to have their membrane removed. To do this, blanch the beans in boiling water for a few seconds then refresh in cold water; the membrane will now pull away quite easily. Peas and beans can be eaten raw or cooked.

    Okra- Or ladies’ fingers. They contain a sticky, dew-like substance that acts as a thickening agent in dishes. For this reason, if cooking whole, they should be trimmed but not cut around the top - by keeping the top intact the sticky interior is not released. When overcooked the juice within the okra becomes slimy, so only cook until just tender.

When overcooked the juice within the okra becomes slimy, so only cook until just tender.

  • 5 Main Fruit Categories

  • Fruits can be divided into 5 main categories:

    1. Citrus
    2. Berries
    3. Hard Fruits
    4. Stone Fruits
    5. Exotic Fruits

    All can be used in a number of ways, both sweet and savoury, to add flavour to a dish or to form the main part of the dish itself.

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • The Citrus Group contains oranges, lemons, limes, grapefruits, tangerines, clementines, and other such hybrids. 

    They all contain relatively high levels of citric acid, which is what gives lemons and limes their tart, sharp flavour.

  • Lesson Summary

  • These are the key points covered in the module:
    • Stocks form the backbone of classical cookery and are an essential component in many dishes. They are simply an extraction of flavour from meat, poultry, vegetables or other ingredients into water. Stocks are commonly divided into two main types, white and brown.
    • Once a stock has been made, chill down to 5°C as quickly as possible. Once cooled, cover, label and keep refrigerated at 5°C or below. They can also be frozen at -18°C or lower. Reheat to a boiling point for 2 minutes before use. This will destroy any harmful bacteria.
    • Sauces are an integral part of any dish. They serve to marry components adding richness, moisture, and an additional layer of flavour and texture. It is often said that all sauces have their origins in one of the five ‘mother sauces’.
    • Fruits and vegetables are by far the largest food groups. They can be prepared as a meal in themselves or as an accompaniment to a meat protein. Both fruits and vegetables can be divided into separate groups and sub-groups, determined by how they grow, the part of the plant being used, and the particular species.
    • Fruits can be divided into 5 main categories: citrus fruits, berries, hard fruits, stone fruits, exotic fruits. All can be used in a number of ways, both sweet and savoury, to add flavour to a dish or to form the main part of the dish itself.

  • Learning Outcomes

  • By the end of this topic you will be able to: 
    • Classify the 3 categories of beef cuts.
    • Identify the temperature needed for each level of cooking for different beef cuts.
    • Recognize the different cuts of lamb and their cooking methods.
    • Discuss why it's crucial to thoroughly cook pork meat.
    • Explain why freshness is key to good offal.

  • Introduction

  • Meat is the flesh of an animal found beneath the skin and above or around the bone. Offal is the organs of an animal, such as heart, liver, kidneys, etc.
  • Beef is perhaps the most prized of all meats. The prime cuts of prime cattle can command a high price, with the cost involved in raising a calf to slaughter being expensive enough to cause even the lesser cuts to be relatively expensive.

    The price of beef will vary according to the rearing methods used, the cut of meat, and the cattle from which it came: expensive cattle such as Charolais, Angus, Welsh Black or Wagyu can cost many times more than the equivalent mass reared cattle.

  • Meat is the flesh of an animal found beneath the skin and above or around the bone. Offal is the organs of an animal, such as heart, liver, kidneys, etc.
  • Beef is perhaps the most prized of all meats. The prime cuts of prime cattle can command a high price, with the cost involved in raising a calf to slaughter being expensive enough to cause even the lesser cuts to be relatively expensive.

    The price of beef will vary according to the rearing methods used, the cut of meat, and the cattle from which it came: expensive cattle such as Charolais, Angus, Welsh Black or Wagyu can cost many times more than the equivalent mass reared cattle.

  • Temperature 

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • The level of cooking of beef is determined by temperature. This is used for all steaks and roast joints; long-cook cuts of beef do not apply to this rule. Short cook cuts are the more tender cuts of meat, they become tough when overcooked; long cook cuts are naturally more tough, they become more tender the longer they are cooked.
  • The ‘temperature’ refers to the internal temperature of the meat at its thickest point. This can be determined by using a temperature probe on larger joints of beef, or by touch when cooking a steak. The cooking temperatures of a steak range from blue to well done. Roasting joints are not cooked blue, they should achieve an internal temperature of 55-60°C, which equates to a medium rare roast.

    Meat is cooked to this temperature as this allows for residual cooking; this is when the residual heat that has accumulated inside the meat continues to cook it for a few minutes after removal from the oven/pan/grill. It is for this reason that meat must be rested before slicing or serving.

  • Lamb

  • Lamb is a sheep of less than six months old, and is prized for its sweet, flavoursome meat. 

    Older lamb can also be eaten, though it is less popular - mutton is taken from a sheep of 12-20 months old, and hogget lies in between at around 6-12 months. As the sheep ages its meat becomes tougher and stronger in flavour; lamb is light compared to mutton, and requires less cooking.

    The picture on the right shows the different types of cuts of lamb.

  • Pork

  • The pig is an extremely versatile animal, with almost every part of it being edible - from the nose right down to the tail. 

    It also forms the basis of many cured products such as hams, bacons and salamis.

    Pork meat is taken from the domesticated pig, which was in turn bred from wild hogs and boars.

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • Rarer breed pig and wild boar meat is now widely available and should be butchered in much the same way as any other pork, though boar may require longer cooking times. The picture above shows the different types of pork cuts.

  • Venison

  • Venison is the meat of the deer. It can vary in strength from mild to very ‘gamey’ depending on the type and sex of the deer, and whether it has been ‘hung’. 

    Hanging is a common practice used with game meats and birds; it involves hanging the carcass of the animal in a cool environment to allow natural enzymes within the meat to develop. 

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • This serves to tenderise the meat and develop its flavour. Farmed venison is milder in flavour and is rarely hung. As with all game meats, wild or shoot game must be treated with care.

    Animals that are culled by shooting can suffer damage to the meat which can cause it to spoil very quickly. Meats with shot damage should be discarded. Shot wounds should be clean and thoroughly checked for leftover shot, which could pose a choking hazard if served. Venison is a very lean meat that can become dry very quickly during cooking. For this reason, venison is almost always served pink, or else it is stewed, braised or casseroled for a long time to break down the muscle fibres. Fallow deer, roe deer and red deer are the most commonly available types.

    Animals that are culled by shooting can suffer damage to the meat which can cause it to spoil very quickly. Meats with shot damage should be discarded.   • Venison

  • Venison is the meat of the deer. It can vary in strength from mild to very ‘gamey’ depending on the type and sex of the deer, and whether it has been ‘hung’. 

    Hanging is a common practice used with game meats and birds; it involves hanging the carcass of the animal in a cool environment to allow natural enzymes within the meat to develop.

  • Lesson Summary

  • These are the key points covered in the module:
    • Beef is perhaps the most prized of all meats. The price will vary according to the rearing methods used, the cut of meat, and the cattle from which it came.
    • Beef cuts, as with all cuts of meat, can be divided into 3 categories: those that require long, slow cooking; those that are best roasted; and those that are best quickly grilled or fried. The preferred cooking method for each cut is determined by the size and texture of the meat.
    • Lamb is a sheep of less than six months old and is prized for its sweet, flavoursome meat. As the sheep ages, its meat becomes tougher and stronger in flavour.
    • The pig is an extremely versatile animal, with almost every part of it being edible - from the nose right down to the tail. It also forms the basis of many cured products such as hams, bacon and salamis. Pork meat is taken from the domesticated pig, which was bred from wild hogs and boars.
    • Venison is the meat of the deer. It can vary in strength from mild to very ‘gamey’ depending on the type and sex of the deer, and whether it has been ‘hung’. Hanging is a common practice used with game meats and birds. This serves to tenderise the meat and develop its flavour.
    • Offal is the edible internal organs of an animal. It requires careful handling and storage, with freshness being key to good offal.

  • Learning Outcomes

  • By the end of this module you will be able to:
    • Identify the different anatomy of poultry.
    • Recall the two groups that poultry is divided into.
    • Summarize the types of poultry commonly available.
    • Classify fresh poultry by appearance and smell.
    • Describe different cooking methods of Poultry.
    • Recognize the correct cooking temperature and times for poultry.

  • Poultry

  • Poultry is the term used to describe all domestic fowl; that is, winged animals bred for food. This usually means chicken, turkey, goose and duck but it can also include domestically bred guinea fowl, pheasant and quail. 

    Other wild birds, such as woodcock and wood pigeon are classed as game. Although the texture and flavour of the meat differs between different types of poultry, the anatomy is largely the same. 
  • This means that, unlike most hoofed animals, the butchery techniques used for poultry are essentially the same no matter what the bird. 

    The breast and legs contain the most meat and are the most commonly eaten cuts of poultry, though the neck, wings, feet and even the comb can be eaten.

  • Poultry

  • Poultry is the term used to describe all domestic fowl; that is, winged animals bred for food. This usually means chicken, turkey, goose and duck but it can also include domestically bred guinea fowl, pheasant and quail. 

    Other wild birds, such as woodcock and wood pigeon are classed as game. Although the texture and flavour of the meat differs between different types of poultry, the anatomy is largely the same. 
  • This means that, unlike most hoofed animals, the butchery techniques used for poultry are essentially the same no matter what the bird. 

    The breast and legs contain the most meat and are the most commonly eaten cuts of poultry, though the neck, wings, feet and even the comb can be eaten.

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • Boning 

  • All poultry is butchered in much the same way. The example given below uses a chicken, but the same technique can be used with turkey, duck, goose and other poultry. When roasting a whole bird it is advisable to remove the wishbone before trussing and roasting. The wishbone sits at the neck end of the bird and its removal allows for easier carving once the bird has been cooked.

    To remove the wishbone:

    1. Pull back the skin from the neck cavity and locate the wishbone using your fingers. The bone will run either side of the cavity and is connected at the top by a long fin.

    2. Using a sharp knife, cut down either side of the cavity. Scrape the exposed bone on either side
    using the blade of the knife

    3. Cut a slice down the other side of the bone and gently pull from both sides of the cavity to release the wishbone. It may take a little force to remove the upper join.

    4. Scrape the other side of the bone as you pull away, and remove the wishbone.

  • Roasting Poultry

  • Cooking times and techniques vary from bird to bird. Whole roasted birds, particularly smaller ones, may benefit from barding (a protective layer of bacon or fat) over the breasts before roasting. The fattier waterfowl must have some of their fat rendered away during cooking. This produces a crisp, flavoursome layer above the meat. Unrendered fat is unappetising.

  • Lesson Summary

  • These are the key points covered in the module:
    • Poultry is the term used to describe all domestic fowl; that is, winged animals bred for food. This usually means chicken, turkey, goose and duck but it can also include domestically bred guinea fowl, pheasant and quail.
    • The breast and legs contain the most meat and are the most commonly eaten cuts of poultry, though the neck, wings, feet and even the comb can be eaten.
    • Poultry can be divided into two groups: Waterfowl and Landfowl.
    • When roasting a whole bird it is advisable to remove the wishbone before trussing and roasting. The wishbone sits at the neck end of the bird and its removal allows for easier carving once the bird has been cooked.
    • Duck contains a lower proportion of meat to fat and bone when compared to chicken. Their fat content is such that the fat rendered from the skin during the cooking process is sufficient to cook the breast. Duck fat has great flavour and can be used as a cooking medium for frying and roasting foods.
    • Cooking times and techniques vary from bird to bird. Whole roasted birds, particularly smaller ones, may benefit from barding (a protective layer of bacon or fat) over the breasts before roasting.
    • When roasting a whole bird it is advisable to remove the wishbone before trussing and roasting. The wishbone sits at the neck end of the bird and its removal allows for easier carving once the bird has been cooked.

    • The breast and legs contain the most meat and are the most commonly eaten cuts of poultry, though the neck, wings, feet and even the comb can be eaten.
    • Poultry can be divided into two groups: Waterfowl and Landfowl.
    • When roasting a whole bird it is advisable to remove the wishbone before trussing and roasting. The wishbone sits at the neck end of the bird and its removal allows for easier carving once the bird has been cooked.
    • Duck contains a lower proportion of meat to fat and bone when compared to chicken. Their fat content is such that the fat rendered from the skin during the cooking process is sufficient to cook the breast. Duck fat has great flavour and can be used as a cooking medium for frying and roasting foods.
    • Cooking times and techniques vary from bird to bird. Whole roasted birds, particularly smaller ones, may benefit from barding (a protective layer of bacon or fat) over the breasts before roasting.
    • When roasting a whole bird it is advisable to remove the wishbone before trussing and roasting. The wishbone sits at the neck end of the bird and its removal allows for easier carving once the bird has been cooked.
